title: Prince Charles says Britains role slave trade left indelible stain history
story: Prince Charles will today tackle the ‘abject horror’ of Britain’s role in slavery in an emotive speech in GhanaPrince Charles will today tackle the ‘abject horror’ of Britain’s role in slavery in an emotive speech in Ghana.Although he will not make a full apology for what he describes as an ‘indelible stain’, he will not avoid Britain’s involvement in the trade.Charles and Camilla are on a four-day tour to strengthen trade relations with Ghana and support community projects. On the last leg of the visit, the Prince of Wales will speak at the International Conference Centre at the invitation of President Nana Akufo-Addo.While he will mainly use it to pay tribute to Ghana’s role in the Commonwealth, Charles was keen to reference the slave trade in Ghana and Britain and Europe’s role in it.He also wanted to use the occasion to highlight Britain’s determination to tackle modern slavery.The prince was visibly moved by a visit to Fort Christiansborg in Osu, a suburb of the capital Accra, during which he was told of its chilling history.Built in 1661, the fort – also known as Osu Castle – was used by the Danes to hold slaves before they were sent to the New World.In the 19th century, it became the headquarters of the local British government.Colombian star of Royal Ballet reveals he used...How the nation will remember next week: Hour-by-hour what's...Share this article    The Prince of Wales will mainly use his speech to pay tribute to Ghana’s role in the Commonwealth (pictured being greeted by dancers at Fort Christiansborg in Accra, Ghana)    Meghan and her mother Doria RaglandIn an unprecedented step, the Duchess of Sussex’s mother is expected to fly in from the US to spend Christmas with the Queen.Meghan’s mother Doria Ragland, 62, is said to have been invited to Sandringham to join her daughter and the rest of the Royal Family.The honour was not extended to Carole and Michael Middleton, parents of the Duchess of Cambridge.A royal source said it was ‘a very thoughtful gesture’, adding: ‘It’s a mark of the Queen’s respect for Meghan and an acknowledgement that she doesn’t have any other relations in this country – unlike Kate, who has a very close family.’The Middletons have joined the Queen at church on Christmas morning, but stayed with William.                                                     At the bottom were dungeons in which enslaved Africans were kept for up to six months as they awaited transportation.During a sombre moment in searing heat, Charles paused at the foot of the stairs, known as ‘the door of no return’, to reflect on the fort’s horrific past.In his speech today, he is expected to say: ‘The histories of our two nations are closely intertwined, and while today we enjoy shared opportunity, we can never forget that our past has sometimes borne witness to tragedy and loss and, at times, profound injustice. At Osu Castle, it was especially important to me – as indeed it was on my first visit there 41 years ago – that I should acknowledge the most painful chapter of Ghana’s relations with the nations of Europe, including the United Kingdom. The appalling atrocity of the slave trade, and the unimaginable suffering it caused, left an indelible stain on the history of our world.‘While Britain can be proud that it later led the way in the abolition of this shameful trade, we have a shared responsibility to ensure that the abject horror of slavery is never forgotten, that we abhor the existence of modern slavery and that we robustly promote and defend the values which today make it incomprehensible, to most of us, that human beings could ever treat each other with such utter inhumanity.’Charles will also pay tribute to the strength of the relationship between the UK and Ghana.He is keen to highlight the country’s role in the Commonwealth and stress how, by acting within the organisation, it can play an important role over environmental issues and rapid urbanisation.He will also acknowledge Ghana as an example to the region and to the world of a stable democracy, a beacon of tolerance and ersity.In his speech, the prince is expected to say: ‘The Commonwealth should strive for renewed relevance in the lives of its citizens and should draw upon its unparalleled networks of professional expertise, to offer practical solutions to some of the most pressing challenges of our time, many of which are increasingly deep seated and deeply integrated.‘No issue is more pressing than that of climate change.’

title: The Isle Dogs big money
story: Then and now: The old entrance to Millwall Outer Dock, West Ferry Road, 1982 (left) and today (right). Major regeneration through the 1980s changed the face of the Docklands, making it a totem of Thatcher's neo-liberal Britain and ushering in an era of luxury housing at the expense of the local communitiesPhotographer Mike Seaborne's stunning collection, taken between 1982 and 1987, shows the stark transformation of the Docklands and foreshadows the gentrification race that would spread through the capital in years to come.The Isle of Dogs, the teardrop shaped peninsula within a large meander of the River Thames, suffered irrevocably from the Second World War with evacuation, casualties and mobilisation reducing the population to just 8,000.London Calling: From Teddy Boys of the 1950s to grime raves...100 years ago the first tanks rumbled into faltering action...Life at the Last Post: Rare pictures from 1960s Aden reveal...Share this articleEntire streets were destroyed, schools razed and churches laid waste following brutal aerial assaults during the Battle of Britain.Following two decades of relentless decline, by the 1970s, the Isle of Dogs resembled what in the 1930s had been termed a 'Distressed Area'.          Islanders waiting for a boat to join the 'Docklands Armada', Cuba Street, 1985: The third ‘People’s Armada to Parliament’ was organised by docklands community groups to petition the government to meet the needs of locals. The event comprised of a flotilla of decorated cruisers which progressed from Docklands up the river to the Houses of Parliament and back to Jubilee Gardens on the Bermondsey riverfront. Islanders include Di Ferdani, Dot Anderson and others          Docklands community poster, Roserton Street, 1984: The collection also hints at the growing - if ultimately futile - political and social resistance to the big money flowing in. Graffiti covered walls and a striking advertisement board read: 'Big money is moving in, don't let it push out local people'The docks were closed, factories boarded up or demolished for scrap and a large parts of a once buzzing, thriving community had disappeared. Nonetheless, touching images show the Blitz spirit remained strong in the surviving parts, with immaculately turned out women pictured together happily ahead of community protests and children playing in the streets.However, the collection also hints at the growing - if ultimately futile - political and social resistance to the big money flowing in. The images show how the area has been filled with multimillion pound apartment buildings - a far cry from its industrial past    View north towards the Barkantine Estate from Montrose House, West Ferry Road, 1985:  The Isle of Dogs, a teardrop shaped peninsula along the Thames, suffered irrevocably from the Second World War with evacuation, massive casualties and mobilisation reducing the population to just 8,000. Entire streets were destroyed, schools razed and churches laid waste following brutal aerial assaults during the Battle of Britain. Two young women survey the area from their balcony          Factory floor workers' canteen, Blyth Burrell Colours Ltd, West Ferry Road, 1984: The original Burrell &amp Company, founded in 1852, were oil refiners and manufacturers of paints, varnishes and colours. They came to Millwall in the 1880s and took over existing buildings, including the Plate House, which dates from the 1850s when the shipbuilders, John Scott Russell &amp Co, occupied the site. Two workers on a cigarette break had taken their boots off to rest. Just two years later Burrell's closed down          Mudchute Park Amphitheatre, 1985: Once the Isle of Dogs was declared an Enterprise Zone, the land controlled by the London's Docklands Development Corporation rose from £80,000 per acre in 1981 to £4 million four years later. Nonetheless the community spirit remained and pictures of children tobogganing in the snow offers a glimpse into the lives of those co-existing with the rapid expansion and changing face of the DocklandsGraffiti covered walls and a striking advertisement board read: 'Big money is moving in, don't let it push out local people'.  Ultimately, once the Isle of Dogs was declared an Enterprise Zone, the land controlled by the London's Docklands Development Corporation rose from £80,000 per acre in 1981 to £4 million in 1985.Despite its shipping heritage and extraordinary architecture designed by George Gwilt in 1800, when the changes did come, it came with a ruthlessness and indifference to the residents' sense of identity and their shared history.Burrell’s Wharf then and now: Burrell &ampamp Company were oil refiners and manufacturers of paints, varnishes and colours. From the late 1880s until the early 1920s a number of stores, warehouses and workshops appeared on the site. In 1988 it was converted into a residential area with 400 homes    Geejay's Solarium, corner of West Ferry Road and Ferry Street, 1985: Touching images show the Blitz spirit remained strong in the surviving parts, with immaculately turned out women pictured together smiling, children playing in the streets, and here, three young women relaxing outside of a solarium which was open from 10am to 10pm           Isle of Dogs foreshore looking across the river towards Deptford Creek and Power Station, 1983: Despite its shipping heritage and extraordinary architecture designed by George Gwilt in 1800, when the changes did come, it came with a ruthlessness and indifference to the residents' sense of identity and their history          'The Marshal Keate' pub, Preston Road, 1983: Families were pushed out, business collapsed, buildings were built and the millions started to flow in. Change was afoot and there was, tragically for the residents of the Isle of Dogs, no going back. Three years after this photograph was taken, the pub was demolished to make way for new developmentsFamilies were pushed out, business collapsed, buildings were built and the millions started to flow in. Change was afoot and there was, tragically for the residents of the Isle of Dogs, no going back.Since the 1980s, continued investment in Canary Wharf has brought about colossal change, attracting the likes of Deutsche Bank, KPMG and Barclays, who have all set up home in the skyscrapers that make up the area's iconic skyline. Photographer Mike Seaborne, whose collection is featured in the Hoxton Mini Press book, described the inspiration behind his work: 'The regeneration of London's Docklands has been described as the UK's biggest social experiment of the 20th century.           Chapel House Street, 1984: Families were pushed out, business collapsed, buildings were built and the millions started to flow in. Change was afoot and there was, tragically for the residents of the Isle of Dogs, no going backBalcony view from Montrose House, 1984 and recent: Since the 1980s, continued investment in Canary Wharf has brought about colossal change, attracting the likes of Deutsche Bank, KPMG and Barclays, who have all set up home in the skyscrapers that make up the area's iconic skyline     Photographer Mike Seaborne, whose collection is featured in the Hoxton Mini Press book, said: 'The regeneration of London's Docklands has been described as the UK's biggest social experiment of the 20th century. I was struck by the extent to which the island still retained its traditional industrial character, albeit one clearly in severe decline, and was determined to document the area before the London Docklands Development Corporation, set up in 1981, carried out its transformation''When I began photographing the Isle of Dogs in 1982 it was known that big changes were on the way, though their exact scale and nature was still far from clear. 'I stumbled upon the Isle of Dogs more or less by accident after spending some time photographing the river wharves closer to central London. 'I was struck by the extent to which the island still retained its traditional industrial character, albeit one clearly in severe decline, and was determined to document the area before the London Docklands Development Corporation, set up in 1981, carried out its transformation.'The Isle of Dogs - Before The Big Money is published by Hoxton Mini Press.Police go door-to-door in search of Brighton 'missing girl'A fallen bear cub climbs a snowy mountain cliff to meet its mumBonfire night revellers mock survivors by burning Grenfell tower effigyAlleged reindeer farm employees seen kicking and abusing animalsShocking video of bouncer kneeing a girl in alleged Halloween assaultPeople in Miami line up to cast their early ballotsPrince Charles makes a speech in Ghana and refers to slave tradeChristopher Boon breaks in tears after arrest during investigationTrump makes an entrance at rally in Cleveland a day before electionWomen carrying alcohol and sex toy put bacon on a mosque's doorDrone footage reveals Tower of London as Beefeaters lit 10,000 torchesHammond explains choice to delay cutting stake to £2 on FOBTs

title: Charles Meghan remarkable bond come dysfunctional families
story: Prince Charles and Meghan have forged a remarkable bond due to their dysfunctional family backgroundsThe Prince of Wales and the Duchess of Sussex have forged a remarkable bond due to their dysfunctional family backgrounds, The Mail on Sunday has learned.Charles is deeply sympathetic to his new daughter-in-law Meghan’s family troubles and is impressed with how she has coped with her relatives’ embarrassing outbursts.One of his inner circle said the Prince recognised the House of Windsor has, like the Markle clan, endured ‘so many traumas and crises… and many orces’ of its own.The source said: ‘Because there’s been bad behaviour that’s caused problems in his family, Charles understands how difficult it must be for Meghan. And it has endeared her to him even more.’Those closest to Charles draw a parallel between Meghan’s dignified forbearance in the face of hurtful comments from relatives, and how the Prince stoically endured public criticism from Princess Diana.‘Whatever they felt inside, they’ve both put on a strong public face and not hidden away,’ said another source.The Prince’s close rapport with Meghan, whom he walked down the aisle in place of her absent father, has delighted Prince Harry and senior members of the Royal Family. It is an understanding that has been further strengthened by a shared love of art, history and culture, with Charles describing Meghan as ‘incredibly smart’.Charles and Meghan’s bond is revealed in The Mail on Sunday’s Event magazine today by Royal biographer Angela Levin, who spent a year following the Prince ahead of his 70th birthday later this month.    The Prince’s close rapport with Meghan, whom he walked down the aisle (pictured) in place of her absent father, is said to have delighted Prince HarryCamilla has also warmed to Meghan. ‘Not least because both of them have joined the Royal Family from the outside,’ said a source. ‘Camilla goes out of her way to find time to spend with her, to get to know her and make her feel welcome.’As the tour of Australasia demonstrated, The Duchess’s transition from actress to high-profile Royal has been seamless – something that has gladdened Charles, who believes her Hollywood training has enabled Meghan to withstand intense scrutiny.In addition to the Event profile, The Mail on Sunday has learned from separate sources of a Scottish holiday enjoyed by Charles and the newlyweds over the summer.Charles entertained Harry and Meghan at the Castle of Mey, the late Queen Mother’s remote home in Caithness, telling friends he was ‘tickled pink’ when they agreed to join him. He also invited the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, but they declined.Sources said Charles told a member of his family that the week with his son and daughter-in-law was ‘joyous’. There were coastal walks and a spot of bird watching.‘I think it’s fair to say that Meghan has brought Harry and Charles closer, and Charles is thrilled to have a new daughter-in-law.‘Camilla wasn’t there, she was enjoying a bucket-and-spade holiday with her own children and grandchildren, so I think that made it even more special for Charles.’Meanwhile, Levin paints a portrait of a man who is settled, content and happy – more so than he has been for years. Marriage to Camilla - whom he frequently describes as ‘my darling wife’ – arrested his tendency to melancholy, particularly evident in the bleak period following the death of Princess Diana when his popularity plummeted and many said he was not fit to be King.  As Prince Charles prepares to turn 70, Event reveals a stunning photo album packed full of remarkably intimate pictures documenting his life from a royal baby to his life today as a doting grandfather Event brings you a colourful insight into the life of a prince with photos of Charles in his mother's arms, on tour around the world and  sharing tender moments with his wife Camilla          Princess Anne holds a bunch of daffodils as Prince Charles stands guard over a plant in 1954          The eight-month-old Prince makes an early play for the Crown Jewels as Royal mother and son share a tender moment in the garden of Windlesham Moor, Surrey, in July 1949, where the family lived for two years as they waited for a major refurbishment of Clarence House to be finished          Elizabeth counts her blessings as a parent while the baby Prince counts the balls on his abacus in an outdoor playpen in the grounds of the rented Windlesham Moor, a five-bedroom country house in Sunningdale with two guest rooms combined to make a nursery          Charles reaches for his rabbit which, along with a teddy, some yellow ducks, a submarine and an elephant on wheels called Jumbo, were his favourite first toys. The photo-shoot on these pages was Charles’s first public appearance since his christening in December 1948          Bundled up against the chill for his first visit to Twickenham, the great cathedral of English rugby, for the annual Army versus Navy match in 1955. It was a family outing with his parents, and the Navy won 8-3          Toddler Charles in 1950, clutching his best-loved teddy as he leaves Clarence House with his nurse in a car. Crowds outside awaited news of the birth of his sister Anne          The Queen is a passionate photographer who has travelled with a camera in her handbag throughout her reign. She’s seen here teaching her son some early skills in an image snapped by her midwife, Sister Helen Rowe, who was present for the birth of all the Queen’s children          Charles, aged five-and-a-half, on an official visit to Gibraltar in May 1954, feeding the rock’s famous Barbary apes. Legendary broadcaster Alan Whicker, then a Royal correspondent covering the trip, later revealed: ‘Charles hated them – and so did I’  Never too young to start: Charles aged four saluting during the 1953 Trooping the Colour, his first, while George, on the eve of his third birthday does the same in 2016          Pathe News footage of the 1956 Royal Windsor Horse Show captures the Queen explaining the rules of showjumping to Charles before heading off to present the prizes          The 17-year-old Charles alongside Princess Anne, 14, arriving in Kingston, Jamaica ahead of the 1966 Commonwealth Games. He would play his first ever public polo match on that trip, sporting a regal Number 1 shirt, to the delight of the West Indian crowds          Charles was 11 when his brother Andrew arrived in 1960. He was allowed out of Cheam School for the occasion and sneaked into Buckingham Palace by a side door to be met by a delighted Prince Philip and Princess Anne. He is pictured here a month later, proudly looking into the new baby’s cradle. Prince Edward would complete the family in 1964          Charles, 15, at Euston station with one of his mother’s corgis on his way to holiday in Balmoral, Scotland, 1963          Charles and Anne live the Caribbean dream with Prince Philip as they snatch some family time from their official Royal tour of Jamaica in 1966          Charles was taught to drive by his mother and Metropolitan Police instructors, and is seen here grimacing as he takes the wheel for the first time since passing his test in April 1967          A year earlier and Charles is pictured pulling on a swim hat presented to him during a lifesaving demonstration at Bondi Beach in Sydney, Australia          It’s an ordinary picture of a Cambridge student – feet up, coffee to hand – in his college rooms, but Charles was the first heir to the throne to get a degree. He read anthropology, archaeology and history at Trinity, graduating with a 2:2 in June 1970          A relaxed Charles, 22, greets his seven-year-old cousin Lady Sarah Armstrong Jones with a huge bear hug on the moors near Balmoral during the Royal Family’s annual summer break in 1971. Their relationship is as close as ever they still sketch and paint together at Balmoral, and she is godmother to Prince Harry          The epitome of Seventies chic, Charles and Anne wear fur-lined Eskimo parkas on a 1970 tour of Canada. Despite the fun image, this was a landmark event for Charles, 21. He kicked the trip off alone in Ottawa before his parents and sister arrived, firmly positioning him as a future head of the Commonwealth          Prince Harry, aged two-and-three quarters, shares a secret with his father at Cirencester Polo Club in Gloucestershire, 1987. In their teens both he and William would join Charles on the polo pitch, calling themselves Team Highgrove          Charles, fit but not flying, loses with good grace in the dads’ race during Prince William’s sports day at Wetherby prep school, June 1989. Three years later, he dodged it altogether, citing Royal duties as a way of avoiding a humiliating rerun  Not the War of the Waleses, just Diana having a smashing time with a prop at Pinewood Studios          The king of country pursuits, Charles looks far more at home in his tweed suit and trilby watching the 1982 Grand National at Aintree than Princess Diana, seven months pregnant with Prince William, who had climbed on to a Range Rover bonnet to get a better view          Charles’s Royal protection officer stays out of harm’s way – for once – as he ducks and covers his ears while Harry, aged 11, takes aim at a pheasant. Harry inherited his father’s love of rural pursuits, but his days as a keen shot on Royal estates such as Sandringham, pictured here, may be over. The Duchess of Sussex, an animal-rights campaigner, doesn’t approve of the sport          The loving look that says: 'We got there in the end dear!'          The Prince stays slim by eating just one main meal a day. It keeps him in the kind of shape he showed here windsurfing at Cowes in 1980          Stripping after a polo match in 1975, the Prince shows why he was so eligible...          He’s 13 years older in 1988 but he’s just as buff, with a slim waist, neat six-pack and muscular shoulders. Today Charles can still button up the double breasted herringbone tweed winter coat made for him by Anderson &amp Sheppard in 1987          He has always loved being in and on the water. He’s pictured aged 15 taking a dip in the Aegean Sea during a visit to Greece for the wedding of King Constantine of Greece, a cousin of his father the Duke of Edinburgh          Charles waterskiing on a dining chair perched on a table top at Windsor’s Sunninghill Park. The challenge had been set by his uncle, Lord Snowdon, a notable inventor          Surf’s up for Prince Charles on Bondi Beach, Australia, 1981          Looking to the past and the future, the monarch and her heir at the Order of Bath service, Westminster Abbey, 2014. This was the year the Queen asked Charles to take her place at the ceremony for new members of the Order, fearing she would not make the steep stairs in The Lady Chapel of King Henry VII in her cumbersome robe and heavy train

title: Queen invites Meghans mother Doria spend Christmas Royal Family
story: Meghan Markle's mother Doria (pictured together before May's royal wedding) could be invited to Sandringham to spend Christmas with the Queen and Royal Family, it is claimedAn invitation for Doria would  break with royal precedent as even the Middleton family has not been invited to stay at the Norfolk estate.The Duchess of Cambridge's family has joined the royals at church on Christmas morning but they have stayed at nearby Anmer Hall rather than Sandringham itself. The Queen's invitation would show respect and also acknowledge that Meghan, unlike Kate, has no other family in Britain, the source said.  A spokesperson for Buckingham Palace declined to comment today. Transgender soldier unveiled as the British Army's first...Hundreds of fake poppy appeal products are seized from...Share this articleDoria won widespread praise for her dignity at the royal wedding following weeks of family drama surrounding Meghan's father, Thomas Markle. Mr Markle pulled out because of health problems just days before she was due to walk down the aisle and admitted he had staged paparazzi pictures. He later said he had apologised to both Harry and Meghan and denied staging the shots for money, insisting they were taken in a bid to 'change his image'. Doria was also in London in September  and joined her daughter at an outdoor reception at Kensington Palace to mark the launch of a cookbook.           The Queen (pictured) is said to have asked Doria to join them for the family's first Christmas since Harry and Meghan's wedding as a 'mark of her respect' for the Duchess

title: Kanye West gives 126 460 Chicago DEMOCRATIC mayor campaign post distancing politics
story: Chicago mayoral candidate Amara Enyia speaks as Chance the Rapper, center, and Kanye West listen during a rally Tuesday, Oct. 23 in Chicago, after which he donated $73,540 to her campaign           After the hip-hop megastar shared he was distancing himself from politics, he donated an additional $126,460, bringing his total contributions to the democrat to $200,000On October 23 Kanye, along with Chance the Rapper, appeared front and center at a rally for Enyia in Chicago.Other Democrats have questioned Enyia for accepting money from a high-profile Trump supporter. title: Rare 50p coins selling 3 500 eBay
story: The commemorative coins, which show the word fifty in the style of a traditional dictionary entry, are being sold for up to £3,500 on eBayAnother valued the same commemorative coin at £3,300.User ckyp2009 said: 'Circulating commemorative 50p coin. Only a limited number produced.'Now it's 'snowPEOPLE' not 'snowmen'! Furious parents blast...All aboard! Car lovers get their veteran motors onto the...Share this articleThere are currently 11 eBay listings offering the coin for more than £2,000.Another 18 sellers value their change at more than £1,000, and dozens would set a collector back between £100 and £999.          One user, sally_w55, described the Johnson's Dictionary coin as 'very rare' - but some experts disagree          Another used placed their collectible coin on sale for £3,300 - just £200 less than the most expensive optionBut some eBay sellers don't value the Samuel Johnson coin quite as highly, and have put the 50 pence pieces on the market for their original value.Others have listed the commemorative coin with a 'buy now' value of £3.97 - just a fraction of the £3,500 price tag placed on the most expensive listing. It appears the anniversary coin may not be quite as extraordinary as some of these sellers assumed.          Of the dozens of listings made for the Samuel Johnson coin on eBay, prices range between £3,500 and just 50 penceBut the coin is popular to collectors - with one £1.20 listing having sold more than 150 times.According to the coin experts at Change Checker, the Samuel Johnson coin isn't unusual at all.It has a 'Common' rating on the website's scarcity index - despite the fact it was minted 13 years ago.          There are currently 11 coins on the online marketplace offering the coin for more than £2,000          Another 18 sellers value their Samuel Johnson coins at between £1000 and £2000 a piece          But elsewhere on eBay, the same commemorative coin is selling for a fraction of the priceThe 50 pence piece was released in 2005 to celebrate the 250th anniversary of Samuel Johnson's Dictionary of the English Language.The Royal Mint produced 17,649,000 of the anniversary coins, compared to 22.7million featuring the Royal Arms in 2008.But while this coin may not be as rare as some users believe, there are dozens of  valuable pieces in circulation. A coin featuring the image of Jemima Puddle-Duck was released to mark the 150th anniversary of Beatrix Potter's birth in 2016.          The anniversary coin is also currently being offered with a 'buy it now' price of just £1.20There were only ever 2.1million in circulation and one of the coins recently sold for £106 on the online marketplace.Others in the collection, including a special coloured edition of a Peter Rabbit coin sold only through the Royal Mint, have sold for as much as £600.The coin was originally on sale through the Royal Mint for £55.          Other pricey coins include one featuring Beatrix Potter's Jemima Puddle-Duck, some of which have sold for more than £106 on eBay          Despite having little monetary value, special edition Peter Rabbit coins have sold for more than £20 in the pastAnother silver version of the Peter Rabbit coin, which was released into general circulation, was selling for more than £20 in the same year it was released. But according to Change Checker, the most sought after 50 pence coin in circulation is  the Kew Gardens design, which has been sold on eBay for up to £160.The design, released in 2009, had a mintage of just 210,000 and is the least owned and most requested swap.   The most sought after 50 pence piece is the Kew Gardens design which has previously sold on eBay for as much as £160

title: Indian capital cloud smog pollution level jumps
story: Pollution in Delhi has spiked to 24 times the safe level - amid fears it could get even worse due to firecrackers set off for Diwali. Pictured: Residents battle through smog in the city          Residents walking the street as heavy smog covers New Delhi in Delhi where the rise in pollution has caused concerns for the public's health That is nearly 24 times a recommended level of 25 micrograms per cubic metre on average over a 24-hour period, set by the World Health Organization, which this year said India was home to the world's 14 most polluted cities. The New Delhi area was ranked the sixth most polluted in the world.Anumita Roychowdhury, an executive director at the Centre for Science and Environment think-tank, said that in two particularly bad states farmers burn stubble in their fields to prepare for winter planting.She said: 'Wind speeds dropped to 15 kilometres per hour from 29 and there's a significant jump in crop stubble burning in Punjab and Haryana in the past few hours.'Authorities warn that crop residue burning will peak in the next few days, adding to the fears Indians will celebrate the festival of Diwali on Wednesday, could add to the smoke pollution.            A Delhi Metro train (top) and vehicles drive past amid the heavy smog in New Delhi today, which is feared could get worse during Diwali festival           These pictures show the India Gate in New Delhi on September 19 (top) and the barely visible monument in heavy smog conditions six weeks later on November 2  (bottom)Hospital consultant, 43, who decapitated a premature baby...Girl, 4, ‘is gang-raped in India by nurse and four others’...Villagers run over a tiger in a tractor and beat it to death...5,000 women line up to be whipped by 'priests' believing it...Share this articleMany members of the majority Hindu community will set off celebratory firecrackers during the festival of lights.Diwali, the most important Hindu festival in north India, celebrates the victory of good over evil. In the last few years celebrations have seen air pollution rise to hazardous levels after many firecrackers were set off. Shamika Ravi, a members of the Economic Advisory Council to the Prime Minister, tweeted today: 'Haven’t heard a single firecracker in Delhi, yet the air purifiers are blazing red - showing dangerous levels of pollution. #NotASimpleProblem.' AQA India, a monitor of air quality in the country, tweeted: 'Delhi is now experiencing the worst AQI so far this year. The live streaming camera captured this ghostly looking image of Connaught Place this morning.'The Supreme Court last month allowed the use of 'green' firecrackers for Diwali to try to curb pollution, but it was unclear how the rule would be enforced or whether there was such a thing as an environmentally safe firework.          A man erects a tent to set up a temporary stall for selling Diwali sweets on a foggy day in Greater Noida, near New Delh          A worker sprays water onto trees along a roadside in in New Delh to curb air pollution by combating accumulated dustLower winter temperatures and higher moisture, coupled with lower wind speeds tend to trap pollutants in the atmosphere, added Roychowdhury.The Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology also said that changes in the speed and direction of the wind, and more stubble burning, had made the air more toxic.The sale of air purifiers had surged 40 percent from last year because of increasing public awareness about the effects of pollution on health, company and industry officials said.New Delhi and its satellite cities account for the bulk of air purifier sales but they are picking up in other cities such as Mumbai and Bengaluru.The air purifier market is dominated by Unilever's, Blueair, Honeywell International Inc and Britain's Dyson.

title: Girls bacon mosques door handles worshippers pray inside
story: The pair film themselves as they target the Madina Mosque and Islamic Centre in Stansfield Street in Oldham, Greater Manchester      Mother, 39, is banned from her children's primary school for...Police stop a lorry driver on the M62 after spotting he was...Share this articleIt shows the two women posing for the camera in baseball caps as one holds up what appears to be a sex toy and a roll of sticky tape. She says to the camera: 'Men in black is on a f****** mission. You see this and you'll see the masterpiece at the end.'Giggling excitedly, they leave the property and start walking towards the mosque to 'complete their mission'.          The women pose for the camera in baseball caps as one holds up what appears to be a sex toy and a roll of sticky tapeThe scantily-clad woman makes gun gestures at the camera and rolls around on the ground as her tracksuit-wearing friend swigs a drink and laughs.The second woman warns: 'You'll get arrested, you d*******. You'll get arrested for putting bacon on doors.'But the yob scoffs: 'We're going to get f****** arrested.'Prayer can be heard as the pair approach the building and they appear to lose their nerve when a man spots them loitering.The first woman says: 'Too on top round the front. We need to go round the back. Quickly. We need to run. Can they see us?'          Outraged viewers have called for the women to be arrested after the video appeared on social mediaWhen a bystander challenges them for 'drinking alcohol' outside the mosque they apologise and claim they are 'just waiting for somebody'.One then starts rummaging in a bag and says she is going to 'smack it on the windows'.Her friend says: 'No, don't slap it on the windows. …Put it on the door handles.'The first woman then dangles what appears to be two slices of bacon in front of the camera and places them on the mosque door before sprinting away laughing. General secretary of Madina Mosque, Dara Miah, 44, said: 'I saw the video yesterday and I'm going to report it to the police.'It's not needed.
